headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Toshandra and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the PSEG Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this con
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Toshandra and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the PSEG Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 1:00 p.m. Eastern today, until 11:59 p.m. Eastern on November 3, 2010. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at, www.pseg.com. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call. As you are aware, we released our third quarter 2010 earnings statements earlier today. They are also the release and the attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call. As you are aware, we released our third quarter 2010 earnings statements earlier today. They are also the release and the attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.com in the Investors section. We have also posted a series of slides that detail our operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2010, it will be filed shortly. I'm not going to be the full disclaimer statement or the comments that we have on the difference between operating earnings and GAAP results. However, as you know, the release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so, even if our estimates changes, unless we are absolutely required to do so, obviously. Our release also contains adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings. Please refer to our 8-K today containing the earnings statement and other filings for a discussion of the factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations, and for a reconciliation of those operating earnings to GAAP results. 
I'm now going to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President, and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. Joining Ralph on the call is Caroline Dorsa, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions, and we do ask that you limit yourself to one question and one follow-up. We hope that there'll be plenty of time for all of your questions today. With that, I'll turn the call over to Ralph.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. Earlier this month, we reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share compared with operating earnings of $0.92 per share in 2009's third quarte
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. Earlier this month, we reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share compared with operating earnings of $0.92 per share in 2009's third quarter. Overall, operating earnings benefited from strong weather-related demand. New Jersey experienced the hottest summer on record this year. This stands in contrast to last year's very cool weather conditions.
For the past 3 quarters, we we've saying the economy appears to have stabilized, well that story remains unchanged. The signals coming from employment levels and housing indicate the economy may have bottomed, but as of yet, no signs of a significant recovery have appeared. Company execution was strong in the quarter. Our fossil generating units in particular were available to respond to the increase in demand. And our employees continue to support our results through their constant focus on operating efficiency and cost control. Capital commitments are being met as well. PSEG Power is in the midst of testing the backend technology installed on the Hudson and Mercer Gold stations. These units are expected to meet stringent environmental requirements for sulfur, mercury, nitrous oxides, in particular. PSEG is in the midst of a midst of a $700 million capital program that will produce a 160 megawatts of solar energy. PSEG Energy Holdings has completed the installation of 29 megawatts of solar capacity in New Jersey, Ohio and Florida and is reviewing additional PPA supported solar investments. These are both a few examples: We'll have more details on the capital program later on.
We're moving forward with PSEG substantial capital investment and transmission. The update we're providing you today of PSEG planned capital outlays takes into account the announced reductions and distribution related spending, the delay in construction of the Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line, and PJM's recently approved reconfiguration of the Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson transmission line. The net result will be a capital program yielding annual growth and the utilities the rate base of 9.5% per year over 2010 to 2013, with transmission continuing its role as our most significant area of investment.
We continue to reduce our financial risk and maintain our focus on core markets. PSEG Energy Holdings successfully terminated another 2 cross-border leases during the quarter. Over the past 2 years, the successful termination of 17 leases has reduced Holdings potential tax liability by $1 billion, with one lease remaining in the cross-border lease portfolio.
PSEG Power announced during the quarter, that it is exploring the sale of its Texas Gaspard combined cycle generating capacity. If successful, we expect the sale to close in the first quarter of 2011. We've been saying that we need to get it bigger in Texas or to get out, and we have not found appropriate opportunities to grow in that market. The sales of the Texas assets will reduce overall size of the of the portfolio by 2,000 megawatts, but it will improve returns on the portfolio and keep the focus squarely on the markets and assets with the highest value. Our results for the quarter and year-to-date continue to support our full-year operating earnings guidance of $3 to $3.25 per share. We experienced the benefits on an improvement in weather-related demand on our pricing this summer, which continues to demonstrate the location of value of our assets. This is said another way, basis returned with demand, albeit at weather driven. 
The Power markets to however, remain challenging. The price is natural gas is falling faster and further that implied by the forward curve. Our reported results continue to benefit from higher priced legacy hedges which was scheduled to expire in 2011 and 2012. As you know, the relatively high embedded cost of energy in our hedges under the Basic Generation Service, as we refer to the BGS contract, versus today's market prices led to the entry of new retail suppliers into the marketplace. An increase in market penetration by retail supplies accelerates the impact on margins that would happen eventually from the reset of the BGS contract prices. We're working hard to address the market challenges. We're focused on reducing O&M without sacrificing reliability, our financial condition remains strong, the markets we serve rimming to constrain, and we are well-positioned for the potential new EPA regulations.
Our efforts to build an organization that focuses on maximizing efficiency, promoting renewables and building a sustainable energy strategy have not gone unnoticed. Just PSEG was added to the Dow Jones' sustainability world Index for the first time this year, having been on the national index for the prior 2 years. And PSEG was recognized by the Carbon Disclosure Project for its efforts to reduce emissions and mitigate the risks of climate change. We aren't immune to decline in market prices, but we are well-positioned to be to meet these challenges. Now let me turn the call over to Caroline, but I will return prior to the question-and-answer period for a few closing remarks.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. I will review our quarterly operating earnings, as well as the outlook for full-year results by subsidiary company. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per sh
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. I will review our quarterly operating earnings, as well as the outlook for full-year results by subsidiary company. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share versus operating earnings of $0.92 per share in last year's third quarter. 
Slide 4 provides the reconciliation of operating income to income from continuing operations and net income for the quarter. As you can see on Slide 9, PSEG Power continues to provide the largest contribution to earnings. Power reported operating earnings of $0.70 per share, compared with $0.71 per share last year.
PSE&G reported operating earnings of $0.30 per share, compared to $0.17 per share last year. And Energy Holdings reported operating earnings of $0.05 per share compared with a negligible contribution to earnings a year ago. The parent company reported earnings of $0.01 per share this year compared with earnings of $0.04 per share a year ago. We provided as always, the waterfall charts on slides 11 and 12 that take you through the neck changes in quarter-over-quarter and year-to-date operating earnings by business. And now I'll go through each company in more detail starting with Power.
As shown on Slide 14, PSEG Power reported operating earnings for the quarter of $0.70 per share compared with $0.71 per share a year ago. The operating environment in the quarter benefited from extremely warm weather as Ralph mentioned, a sharp contrast to the operating environment of a year ago. A 10% increase in generation volume at Sparks spreads during the quarter improved Power's earnings by $0.04 per share. While we had a 10% increase in generation during the quarter, the improvement came primarily from Power's coal and gas units. A 17 day unplanned outage at the Salem 1 unit, which you may recall we mentioned in the July call, reduced generation from the nuclear fleet during the quarter, and reduced earnings by $0.03 per share. So given the different fuel mix of the cost of the outage combined, the increase in output resulted in a net increase and earnings of $0.01 per share.
While we realize the benefit from the net increase in generation, the price received for base load generation declined as a result of lower contract hedged prices versus prior year. This reduced Power's earnings by $0.04 per share. We can also see that weather had a positive effect on BGS load, adding $0.03 per share to earnings. Slightly offsetting this was the reduction to BGS results based on the impact of migration, which hurt Power's earnings by $0.01 per share. The impact of migration during the quarter, was in line with our revised forecast. We estimate that approximately 22% to 24% of the loads supplied to BGS migrated to other suppliers at the end of September, but we don't have the final September data yet. This is approximately steady with the level we saw as you may recall at the end of the second quarter.
Our forecast assumes further erosion on margin of $0.01 per share in the fourth quarter, which is consistent with the upper end of our prior guidance of a $0.02 to $0.04 per share impact of migration for the full year versus 2009. We're now forecasting about $0.04.
Market prices for energy remain lower than the embedded price for energy in the BGS contract, and this dynamic has led to the entry of new retail suppliers into the market. For your modeling purposes, while we don't specifically forecast migration, keep in mind that each 5% of customer migration from BGS would reduce Power's earnings by about a $1.05 per share on an annualized basis at current prices.
In addition, the continued erosion in margin on certain wholesale electric energy supply contracts reduced earnings by $0.02 per share. Recall that these contracts are market to market. Also, realized gains on investments in the Rabbi Trust fund added $0.01 per share to Power's earnings. And the decline in the effective tax rate aided earnings by about $0.01 per share. The increase in volume from the fossil fleet and lower average prices resulted in gross margins for the quarter, a $57 per megawatt hour, compared with $64 per megawatt hour during the third quarter of 2009. Power's gross margins were significantly increased -- by influenced by an increase in generation from coal-fired fleet at a higher cost of fuel given the outage of Salem 1 versus year-ago levels. Generation from coal-fired fleets increased 40% during the quarter, versus last year in response to weather-related demand and an improvement in dark spreads from the levels experienced earlier in the year. The combined cycle fleet also benefited from market opportunities with an 11% increase in generation versus last year, and operated at an average capacity factor of 59% in the quarter.
The increase in coal-fired generation for the quarter and year-to-date has reduced our inventory of coal. We've also exercise the flexibility that exists in our contracts reduced delivery of coal. And the completion of the back end technology work at Hudson and Mercer this quarter will provide greater flexibility with regard to our coal supplied by reducing the need for the low sulfur Indonesian coal burned at Hudson in 2011 when the BET is expected to go into service.
Our coal supply needs over the intermediate term will be lower than historical requirements. Continued weakness in forward dark spreads is expected to reduce coal-fired generation for 2011 to about 8 to 9 terawatt hours. A reduction in output has effectively like that our supply, recontracting and existing supply should be sufficient at this point to meet 2011's coal requirements.
Power's operating earnings for 2010 are still forecast at $1.60 billion to $1.135 billion compared to operating earnings for the 2009 of $1.205 billion. Full-year operating earnings will be affected by continued lower energy pricing. Power continues to hedge its expected generation in future years, consistent with past practice. At the end of September, approximately 68% of Power's anticipated coal and nuclear generation for 2011 is hedged at an average price of $71 per megawatt hour. This compares with an average hedged price for energy in 2010 of $72 per megawatt hour. These hedges reflect a PJM West Forward Energy price embedded in BGS of $70 per megawatt hour in 2008, $57 per megawatt hour in 2009, and $50 per megawatt hour in 2010. And as you know, the current PJM West forward prices are is approximately $40 per megawatt hour range today.
These figures don't reflect the potential impact of increased levels of customer migration, which could reduce the level of Power supplied under existing BGS contracts. As I just mentioned, incremental migration equal to about 5% of customer load would reduce earnings by $0.015 per share. If you run out of the math, an additional loss of about 50% of load would reduce our average hedged price in 2011 to about $67 per megawatt hour.
Now let's turn to PSE&G. PSE&G reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $0.30 per share, compared with $0.17 per share for the third quarter of 2009, as shown on Slide 22. PSE&G's results were influenced by the electric and gas rate relief effective in June and July of 2010, respectively, which improves earnings by $0.05 per share. And earnings also benefited from a return on a capital invested in the capital stimulus, energy efficiency and solar investment programs approved in 2009 by the Board of Public Utilities. And these programs added about $0.01 per share to earnings.
As Ralph mentioned, New Jersey experienced the hottest summer on record in 2010. And we estimate an increase in weather-related demand added about $0.03 per share to earnings. An increase in transmission revenues effective at the start of the year, added $0.01 per share to earnings this quarter.
A decline in operating and maintenance expense during the quarter, improved earnings by $0.02 per share, and realized gains on investments in the Rabbi Trust also added $0.02 per share for the Utility's earnings. And the decline in the effective tax rate added about $0.01 per share. These items more than offset an increase in depreciation and interest expense associated with higher levels of capital investment, which together reduce earnings by about $0.02 per share.
PSE&G's operating earnings for 2010 are forecast at $425 million to $455 million, the same as our prior guidance compared with 2009's operating earnings of $321 million. Operating earnings will be influenced by a full year of return on capital projects approved by the BPU in 2009, the June and July 2010 increases in electric and gas distribution rates, an increase in transmission rates, a forecast decline in operating and maintenance expenses, and the weather-related impact on sales.
We've updated PSE&Gs capital budget for 2010 to 2012, and we're providing you with initial forecast of PSE&Gs 2013 capital expenditures.
PSE&G's revised budget for 2010 to 2012 calls for capital expenditures of $4.5 billion with plans to spend $1.6 billion in 2013, bringing the capital budget for this 4-year period to approximately $6.1 billion. And on Slide 25, you can see a breakdown of the spending by category and by year. This revised capital program recognizes the two-year delay in the in-service date of the Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line, the reconfiguration and delay in operation of the Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson transmission project, and the reduction in distribution spending.
In fact, distributions it spending is lower by about $425 million through 2012 versus the prior guidance we gave you earlier in the year. This should increase the proportion of our expenditures that earn a contemporaneous return. For example, transmission-related capital spending now represents $3.1 billion, or about 50% of the capital budget for the 4 year period. Of course the number of these transmission projects depend upon our receipt of all the necessary approvals.
At the end of 2013, PSE&G's investment and transmission will represent about 31% of its consolidated rate base. Distribution-related capital spending is forecast at $2.2 billion for 2010 to 2013. Future capital spending on distribution is aligned with the forecast levels of depreciation to support earning our authorized return.
PSE&G's investment program is expected to result in annual rate-based growth of about 9.5% per year over this period. Supportive regulatory recovery mechanisms and a constant focus on cost control should support PSE&G's earning its authorized return with growth in capital providing for growth in PSE&G's earnings. In the past 12 month period, PSE&G's distribution ROE was 9.5%, reflecting only one quarter of results is the completion of the rate case. 
Now I'll turn to PSEG Energy Holdings. Energy Holdings reported operating earnings of $24 million, or $0.05 per share for the third quarter of 2010, versus an operating loss of $1 million during the third quarter of 2009. Operating earnings benefited from the successful termination of 2 cross-border leases during the quarter, which resulted in a gain of $0.03 per share, which matched the similar level termination related gains recorded in the year ago quarter. And results also benefited from the absence of a premium paid on the debt exchange with Power of $0.04 per share, as well as the decline in interest expense of $0.01 per share.
The successful termination of the 2 cross-border leases during the quarter, reduced Holdings' potential net cash exposure to $330 million on this issue at the end of September. And recall that Holdings has $320 million on deposit with the IRS to defray potential interest cost associated with this issue.
Holdings operating earnings for 2010 are forecast at $30 million to $40 million compared to 2009's operating earnings of $43 million. The loss of income on terminated leases and a reduction in gains from the termination of leases will be partially offset by lower financing costs and tax benefits from a startup of solar projects in Ohio and Florida.
Finally, a few other items. PSEG Power indicated during the quarter, that it is exploring the potential sale of our two 1,000 MW each combined cycle generation facilities in Texas through an auction process. The sales dependent upon the receipt of offers that we feel reflect the appropriate value for the assets. And should we decide to sell, the scheduled would call for closing to occur during the first quarter of 2011. Finally, just in the, we completed several transactions during the quarter, at PSE&G to finance its capital program and refinance high cost debt. We issued $250 million of 10-year paper at 3.5%, and refinanced the $100 million of 6.4% tax exempt bonds with the issuance of tax exempt paper as multi-mode or annual put bonds with an initial term rate of 1.2%. Holdings recently announced its intention to call debt in December 2010 for the redemption of the remaining $127 million of outstanding principal balance of its 8.5% senior notes that are due in June 2011. Those conclude my remarks and comments on some of our financings. I now like to turn the call back to Ralph for some final comments before of course we open the call up to your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Caroline. A few points to highlight. In conversations with many of you, we have heard concerns expressed about transmission. And we've heard concerns about migration and the impact on Powers margins. We hope that we've answered your questions surr
componenttext: Thanks, Caroline. A few points to highlight. In conversations with many of you, we have heard concerns expressed about transmission. And we've heard concerns about migration and the impact on Powers margins. We hope that we've answered your questions surrounding transmission. Now while it isn't easy to build these lines, we're committed to investing in the projects that will improve the reliability of our system. And as you can see, it remains the single largest capital program for PSE&G. We've also provided you with some guidance around the potential impact of migration on our results. While we're not pleased with the associated loss of margin, the more fundamental concern is the forward price of natural gas and its effect on electricity prices. And candidly, we're pleased to see some of you have addressed this issue in your forecast. Now while we aren't immune to declining prices, we are working to mitigate the impact through cost control where we can and through growth investments. So now we'll open up the lines to your questions.

componenttextpreview: Dan, there's multiple approval processes. So it starts with the designation by PJM that it's in the RTEP, the Regional Transmission Expansion Plan, and it's safe to conclude that all of these projects are in the RTEP and all of these expenditure level. Th
componenttext: Dan, there's multiple approval processes. So it starts with the designation by PJM that it's in the RTEP, the Regional Transmission Expansion Plan, and it's safe to conclude that all of these projects are in the RTEP and all of these expenditure level. Then there's the rate treatment at FERC. As you know, we have a macro level formula rate treatment at FERC. Some of the projects received a different level of formula rate treatment, incentive adders, construction work in progress and we have received that -- those 2 for Susquehanna-Roseland. We have received that for Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson when it was a 500kV project now it's been redone, we're back in FERC to talk to them about the returns that will be granted. As you see, as they go down this path of what approval to need, the path gets wider and wider with many more branches and tributaries off of that. The widest set up branches and tributaries are of course the environmental approvals and the signing approvals, which I just don't have the information on my fingertips about what all -- what each of these projects are still lacking. Clearly for Susquehanna-Roseland, as we've disclosed in the past, we're working with the National Park Service towards double approval date there.

And they don't engender the kind of siting a position that 500kV aboveground projects and gender.

componenttext: It depends on how you define big and profile. I would say that 500 TV is one that attacks the greatest attention and that would be Susquehanna-Roseland. And the next step below that is 230kV for our system, that's Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson. But a large part of that is an underground construction. So an underground dance do not attract the same amount of concern because it's underground. I'm sorry, but I don't know how else to complete that sentence. So I'd say the one that's the primary focus of attention is Susquehanna-Roseland.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Caroline. Just one other thought as you look at the numbers here and think about the modeling of our spend. Part of the things to keep in mind as you know the in-service states for Susquehanna-Roseland and Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson were dela
componenttext: Dan, this is Caroline. Just one other thought as you look at the numbers here and think about the modeling of our spend. Part of the things to keep in mind as you know the in-service states for Susquehanna-Roseland and Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson were delayed as we said. So in these numbers that we included a Slide 25, just for your information, for Susquehanna-Roseland, we estimate that about $550 million of the total of up to $750 million is in the numbers through 2013 and for Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson, about $250 million to $275 million of the total of $700 million is in the numbers through 2013. So there is some spend as you would expect of these projects as outside our forecast period to 2013 given their in-service states. So if you look at those 2 big amounts and look at the CapEx for transmission, just you can keep the time and proportionality, that might be helpful.

So is it the logic being of course is that the smaller projects going service much more quickly, so the formula rate treatment gets you as close as 2 the contemporary returns for the fields they need to get you.

componenttext: I just have -- everything you've articulated is crystal-clear. But there was one thing I wanted a little more color on. If possible, you talked about it in the first whole paragraph in the press release on PSE&G Power, a 2-cent decline in earnings associated with wholesale electricity any supply contracts that you supplied from the market. Can you go into little more detail on what activity is and what sort of aggregate contribution is, if possible?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we talked about some of these before and these are low transactions that we bid on that in most parts, low transactions that we bid on, whose power be supply through the market. And so because they're not supplied from our assets, which treat thes
componenttext: Yes, so we talked about some of these before and these are low transactions that we bid on that in most parts, low transactions that we bid on, whose power be supply through the market. And so because they're not supplied from our assets, which treat these on a mark to market basis. So every quarter we're marking both sides of that transaction to market and we're putting any changes in that through the P&L. The primary driver of what you see here in the $0.02, is really a function of the same dynamics that are going on in the base business and that is in these low contracts, there is still opportunity for migration out of those types of contracts by the provider. And so, as migration is expected or experienced, and then we forecast it going forward to a large extent based on the experience that we have. We reduced the value of those contracts in terms of what they would return to the company and therefore, we take that mark because their mark to market directly in our earnings as we update those forecasts. So think of this as mark to market, it's not cash, but it's the representation, our misrepresentation of the change in value of those contracts primarily driven by the same thing to talk about in the base business which is the migration of out of these full requirements polar-like contracts.

componenttextpreview: Paul, you're right and you can respect we are in the middle of the sales process now. We didn't even come close to remarking on that question, in terms of what we expect the size of proceeds but in terms of the use of proceeds, if we sell, and we're explo
componenttext: Paul, you're right and you can respect we are in the middle of the sales process now. We didn't even come close to remarking on that question, in terms of what we expect the size of proceeds but in terms of the use of proceeds, if we sell, and we're exploring the sale, so we're not sure. We think we have some good opportunities to deploy capital. But there's no surprises in there, it's what you've been hearing from us. And we have a large capital program and utilities nearly 10% CAGER associated with it and there's some opportunities perhaps revisit some of those programs and expand. Our infrastructure is not getting any younger, and we have found some opportunities and Holdings with some attractive terms and conditions with creditworthy counterparties with new PPAs on the renewable site. We have some speakers we've been building in Power and some upgrades in our nuclear plants that we're looking at and are now within the planning horizon. So we think we have some good opportunities in our core business to deploy that capital if we have to sell.

componenttext: Sure, we only have one lease remaining. In terms of how to think about it, from what we've talking about over the past year, the teams that it's been working hard to terminate these leases at appropriate term. So as you think about all the leases that we've terminated, what's essentially happened is we reduced our tax liability essentially by the cash received from the counterparties coming in and going out. So if the terms are appropriate, we would look to terminate this last lease but of course, we have to talk to the counterparties. If not, we keep the lease. One thing to keep in mind though, that the termination of the lease -- where we are with the IRS, those 2 things continue to happen, independent on each other to some extent, obviously we have to terminate all the lease is to try to have that the IRS given what we have now our exposure on a total basis is about $330 million and we're continuing to have discussions with the IRS is to see if we can come to terms, we'll try to do that but at the same time, we'll continue to try to terminate this lease. So you can really what is that dependent on the other, you can really pursue was blessed that's exactly what we're doing. Given the size of the remaining lease though, in terms of impacted earnings, that will be marginal in terms of what might happen either from its earnings proceeds next year or termination as you know, we have to leases this quarter and $0.03. So it's really a small number, and I think it's a credit to the team's work to really bring us down to lease less.

componenttext: Paul, it's Ralph. Thank you, by the way, for recognizing the condition of the balance sheet, and we are part of that, we worked hard for 4 years now at least, to get it to where it is and we are pleased with that condition. Most of our long investors tell us, "look, we look to you to find good ways to deploy capital and if you can get us attractive risk-adjusted returns, then we want you to use it that way." So we are obviously, disclosing to you the things that we have a high degree of confidence we can invest. What I was trying to say earlier to Paul, was that there are many things like that we consider all the time, some of them we shred the paper is a "no, that one didn't pan up that way we want." But there are others that are percolating and that all organic in nature and that we like and that we think we didn't put the money to good use. So I would rather grow the business with attractive risk-adjusted returns and create a positive MVP investment for our shareholders than something that just as a 0 MVP.

As we burned more breakdown inventories and has a lower price goal from the Adaro.

componenttextpreview: Just to clarify just to give you some pieces of the math maybe help you think that through. In terms of the $0.015, so if you think about what our coal and nuclear output, let me just walk you down just a little bit because that may help. 50% of our coal
componenttext: Just to clarify just to give you some pieces of the math maybe help you think that through. In terms of the $0.015, so if you think about what our coal and nuclear output, let me just walk you down just a little bit because that may help. 50% of our coal and nuclear output in total coal and nuclear is about 40 terawatt hours a year so it's half of 20 terawatt hours. With a migration we've already seen it be just, be just as about 15 terawatt hours. It used to be half now and that's less because of the migration. So if you take 5% of the 15 terawatt hours and you multiply that out by the delta in the embedded PJM West price in the BGS contract with the current level of PJM West price and you roll out that math, you get about a penny.5 so that's how we came up with $0.015 because of the 67 change in the hedge price was simply running that same sort of thinking and the same sort of calculation by taking that out of the hedged amount that we have pulling that migrating BGS load out of hedged amount and then recalculating the weighted average hedge price of the portfolio, keeping in mind that the BGS hedge price has more things in it besides just the energy all those things we talked about in our bar chart relative to the PJM West hedge which would not have hedged things like pieces and at. You just have to do those math in 2 pieces one is about how to do that penny per share database weighted average of our hedge portfolio average price.

componenttext: No. What we're trying to give you a sort of rule of thumb way to think of migration. componenttext: As you know, we're not forecasting '11. It's too soon to know. As we pointed out we do have obviously, retailers out out looking for residential switching. We don't know the success of that yet. So we're not really sure. One thing I just add is keep in mind, we saw levels of migration appear to be similar at the end of this quarter to where they were last quarter, but you also have to keep in mind that there's always a function of the headroom calculation as we call it and with a hot weather in the spike in prices, you saw the headroom actually go the other way remember last in the summer without about it being very high. This year the summer is very low because of the spike in prices. So when we come back to a more normal condition and then we what's happening with residential, it's early to really forecast but that would be.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. I don't think we gave out that number but I know if you take a ruler on the graph you can get to a number similar to that for the hedged amount. So when we provided that disclosure at midyear, we were using the data we had tha
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. I don't think we gave out that number but I know if you take a ruler on the graph you can get to a number similar to that for the hedged amount. So when we provided that disclosure at midyear, we were using the data we had that was a little bit older. What we've done now is to update that hedged price for the assumption of the migration amount that we just talked about. The 22% to 24%. So as we updated that and assume that going forward, that pulled that average price down even though the hedged percentage is not really that different, the average prices has come down. We pulled through the hedge, the migration amount added a little more in hedging and that's how you get back up to the same hedge percentage but the weighted average debt is now a little bit different.

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Toshandra, and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the PSEG Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 1:00 p.m. Eastern today until 11:59 p.m. Eastern on November 3, 2010. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call. As you are aware, we released our third quarter 2010 earnings statements earlier today. They are also, the release, and the attachments are posted on our website at www.pse
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call. As you are aware, we released our third quarter 2010 earnings statements earlier today. They are also, the release, and the attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.com in the Investors section. We have also posted a series of slides that detail our operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2010, it will be filed shortly.
I'm not going to read the full disclaimer statements or the comments that we have on the difference between operating earnings and GAAP results. However, as you know, the release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates changes, unless we are absolutely required to do so, obviously. Our release also contains adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings. Please refer to our 8-K today containing the earnings statement and other filings for a discussion of the factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations and for a reconciliation of those operating earnings to GAAP results.
I am now going to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. Joining Ralph on the call is Caroline Dorsa, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. [Operator Instructions] With that, I'll turn the call over to Ralph.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. Earlier this morning, we reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share compared with operating earnings of $0.92 per share in 2009's third qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. Earlier this morning, we reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share compared with operating earnings of $0.92 per share in 2009's third quarter. Overall, operating earnings benefited from strong weather-related demand. New Jersey experienced the hottest summer on record this year. This stands in contrast to last year's very cool weather conditions.
For the past 3 quarters, we've been saying the economy appears to have stabilized. Well, that story remains unchanged. The signals coming from employment levels and housing indicate the economy may have bottomed, but as of yet, no signs of a significant recovery have appeared. Company execution was strong in the quarter. Our fossil generating units, in particular, were available to respond to the increase in demand, and our employees continue to support our results through their constant focus on operating efficiency and cost control.
Capital commitments are being met as well. PSEG Power is in the midst of testing the back-end technology installed on the Hudson and Mercer coal stations. These units are expected to meet stringent environmental requirements for sulfur, mercury, nitrous oxides, in particular. PSEG is in the midst of a $700 million capital program that will produce a 160 megawatts of solar energy. PSEG Energy Holdings has completed the installation of 29 megawatts of solar capacity in New Jersey, Ohio and Florida and is reviewing additional PPA-supported solar investments. These are but a few examples. Caroline will have more details on the capital program later on.
We're moving forward with PSEG's substantial capital investment and transmission. The update we're providing you today of PSEG's planned capital outlays takes into account the announced reductions and distribution-related spending, the delay in construction of the Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line and PJM's recently approved reconfiguration of the Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson transmission line. The net result will be a capital program yielding annual growth and the utilities rate base of 9.5% per year over 2010 to 2013, with transmission continuing its role as our most significant area of investment.
We continue to reduce our financial risk and maintain our focus on core markets. PSEG Energy Holdings successfully terminated another 2 cross-border leases during the quarter. Over the past 2 years, the successful termination of 17 leases has reduced Holdings' potential tax liability by $1 billion, with one lease remaining in the cross-border lease portfolio.
PSEG Power announced during the quarter that it is exploring the sale of its Texas gas-fired combined cycle generating capacity. If successful, we expect the sale to close during the first quarter of 2011. We've been saying that we need to just get bigger in Texas or to get out, and we have not found appropriate opportunities to grow in that market. The sales of the Texas assets will reduce the overall size of the portfolio by 2,000 megawatts, but it will improve returns on the portfolio and keep the focus squarely on the markets and assets with the highest value.
Our results for the quarter and year-to-date continue to support our full year operating earnings guidance of $3 to $3.25 per share. We experienced the benefits on an improvement in weather-related demand on pricing this summer, which continues to demonstrate the location of value of our assets. Said another way, basis returned with demand, albeit weather-driven.
The power markets, however, remain challenging. The price of natural gas is falling faster and further than implied by the forward curve. Our reported results continue to benefit from higher-priced legacy hedges, which are scheduled to expire in 2011 and 2012. As you know, the relatively high embedded cost of energy in our hedges under the Basic Generation Service, as we refer to as the BGS contract, versus today's market prices led to the entry of new retail suppliers into the marketplace. An increase in market penetration by retail suppliers accelerates the impact on margins that would happen eventually from the reset of the BGS contract prices. We're working hard to address the market challenges. We're focused on reducing our O&M without sacrificing reliability. Our financial condition remains strong, the markets we serve remain constrained, and we're well positioned for potential new EPA regulations.
Our efforts to build an organization that focuses on maximizing efficiency, promoting renewables and building a sustainable energy strategy have not gone unnoticed. PSEG was added to the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index for the first time this year, having been on the national index for the prior 2 years, and PSEG was recognized by the Carbon Disclosure Project for its efforts to reduce emissions and mitigate the risks of climate change. We aren't immune to declining market prices, but we're well positioned to meet these challenges.
Now let me turn the call over to Caroline, but I will return prior to the question-and-answer period for a few closing remarks.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. I will review our quarterly operating earnings as well as the outlook for full year results by subsidiary company. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per sha
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. I will review our quarterly operating earnings as well as the outlook for full year results by subsidiary company. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $1.06 per share versus operating earnings with $0.92 per share in last year's third quarter.
Slide 4 provides the reconciliation of operating income to income from continuing operations and net income for the quarter. As you can see on Slide 9, PSEG Power continues to provide the largest contribution to earnings. Power reported operating earnings of $0.70 per share compared with $0.71 per share last year.
PSE&G reported operating earnings of $0.30 per share compared to $0.17 per share last year. And Energy Holdings reported operating earnings of $0.05 per share compared with a negligible contribution to earnings a year ago. The parent company reported earnings of $0.01 a share this year compared with earnings of $0.04 per share a year ago. We provided, as always, the waterfall charts on Slides 11 and 12 that take you through the net changes in quarter-over-quarter and year-to-date operating earnings by business. And I'll now go through each company in more detail, starting with Power.
As shown on Slide 14, PSEG Power reported operating earnings for the quarter of $0.70 per share compared with $0.71 per share a year ago. The operating environment in the quarter benefited from extremely warm weather, as Ralph mentioned, a sharp contrast to the operating environment of a year ago. A 10% increase in generation volume at sparks spreads during the quarter improved Power's earnings by $0.04 per share. While we had a 10% increase in generation during the quarter, the improvement came primarily from Power's coal and gas units. A 17-day unplanned outage at the Salem 1 unit, which you may recall we mentioned in the July call, reduced generation from the nuclear fleet during the quarter and reduced earnings by $0.03 per share. So given the different fuel mix and the cost of the outage combined, the increase in output resulted in a net increase and earnings of $0.01 per share.
While we realize the benefit from the net increase in generation, the price received for base load generation declined as a result of lower contract hedged prices versus prior year. This reduced Power's earnings by $0.04 per share. We can also see that weather had a positive effect on BGS load, adding $0.03 per share to earnings. Slightly offsetting this was the reduction to BGS results based on the impact of migration, which hurt Power's earnings by $0.01 per share. The impact of migration during the quarter was in line with our revised forecast. We estimate that approximately 22% to 24% of the loads supplied through BGS migrated to other suppliers at the end of September, but we don't have the final September data yet. This is approximately steady with the level we saw, as you may recall, at the end of the second quarter.
Our forecast assumes further erosion in margin of $0.01 per share in the fourth quarter, which is consistent with the upper end of our prior guidance of a $0.02 to $0.04 per share impact of migration for the full year versus 2009. We're now forecasting about $0.04.
Market prices for energy remain lower than the embedded price for energy in the BGS contract, and this dynamic has led to the entry of new retail suppliers into the market. For your modeling purposes, while we don't specifically forecast migration, keep in mind that each 5% of customer migration from BGS would reduce Power's earnings by about a $0.015 per share on an annualized basis at current prices.
In addition, the continued erosion in margin on certain wholesale electric energy supply contracts reduced earnings by $0.02 per share. Recall that these contracts are marked to market. Also, realized gains on investments in the Rabbi Trust fund added $0.01 per share to Power's earnings, and the decline in the effective tax rate aided earnings by about $0.01 per share.
The increase in volume from the fossil fleet and lower average prices resulted in gross margins from the -- for the quarter a $57 per megawatt hour compared with $64 per megawatt hour during the third quarter of 2009. Power's gross margins were significantly increased by -- influenced by an increase in generation from its coal-fired fleet and a higher cost of fuel, given the outage of Salem 1 versus year-ago levels. Generation from the coal-fired fleet increased 40% during the quarter versus last year in response to weather-related demand and an improvement in dark spreads from the levels experienced earlier in the year. The combined cycle fleet also benefited from market opportunities with an 11% increase in generation versus last year and operated at an average capacity factor of 59% in the quarter.
The increase in coal-fired generation for the quarter and year-to-date has reduced our inventory of coal. We've also exercised the flexibility that exists in our contracts to reduce delivery of coal. And the completion of the back-end technology work at Hudson and Mercer this quarter will provide greater flexibility with regard to our coal supply by reducing the need for the low-sulfur Indonesian coal burned at Hudson in 2011 when the BET is expected to go into service.
Our coal supply needs over the intermediate term will be lower than historical requirements. Continued weakness in forward dark spreads is expected to reduce coal-fired generation for 2011 to about 8 to 9 terawatt hours. A reduction in output has effectively lengthened our supply. Re-contracting an existing supply should be sufficient at this point to meet 2011's coal requirements.
Power's operating earnings for 2010 are still forecast at $1.060 billion to $1.135 billion compared to operating earnings for 2009 of $1.205 billion. Full year operating earnings will be affected by continued lower energy pricing.
Power continues to hedge its expected generation in future years, consistent with past practice. At the end of September, approximately 68% of Power's anticipated coal and nuclear generation for 2011 is hedged at an average price of $71 per megawatt hour. This compares with an average hedged price for energy in 2010 of $72 per megawatt hour. These hedges reflect a PGM -- PJM West Forward Energy Price embedded in BGS of $70 per megawatt hour in 2008, $57 per megawatt hour in 2009 and $50 per megawatt hour in 2010. And as you know, the current PJM West Forward Prices are in the approximate $40 per megawatt hour range today.
These figures don't reflect the potential impact of increased levels of customer migration, which could reduce the level of Power supplied under existing BGS contracts. As I just mentioned, incremental migration equal to about 5% of customer load would reduce earnings by $0.015 per share. If you run out the math, an additional loss of about 15% of load would reduce our average hedged price in 2011 to about $67 per megawatt hour.
Now let's turn to PSE&G. PSE&G reported operating earnings for the third quarter of 2010 of $0.30 per share compared with $0.17 per share for the third quarter of 2009, as shown on Slide 22. PSE&G's results were influenced by the electric and gas rate relief effective in June and July of 2010, respectively, which improved earnings by $0.05 per share. And earnings also benefited from a return on the capital invested in the capital stimulus, energy efficiency and solar investment programs approved in 2009 by the Board of Public Utilities. And these programs added about $0.01 per share to earnings.
As Ralph mentioned, New Jersey experienced the hottest summer on record in 2010. And we estimate an increase in weather-related demand added about $0.03 per share to earnings. An increase in transmission revenues effective at the start of the year added $0.01 per share to earnings this quarter.
A decline in operating and maintenance expense during the quarter improved earnings by $0.02 per share, and realized gains on investments in the Rabbi Trust also added $0.02 per share to the utility's earnings. And the decline in the effective tax rate added about $0.01 per share. These items more than offset an increase in depreciation and interest expense associated with higher levels of capital investment, which together reduced earnings by about $0.02 per share.
PSE&G's operating earnings for 2010 are forecast at $425 million to $455 million, the same as our prior guidance, compared with 2009's operating earnings of $321 million. Operating earnings will be influenced by a full year of return on capital projects approved by the BPU in 2009, the June and July 2010 increases in electric and gas distribution rates, an increase in transmission rates, a forecast decline in operating and maintenance expenses and the weather-related impact on sales.
We've updated PSE&G's capital budget for 2010 to 2012, and we're providing you with our initial forecast of PSE&G's 2013 capital expenditures. PSE&G's revised budget for 2010 to 2012 calls for capital expenditures of $4.5 billion, with plans to spend $1.6 billion in 2013, bringing the capital budget for this 4-year period to approximately $6.1 billion. And on Slide 25, you can see a breakdown of the spending by category and by year. This revised capital program recognizes the 2-year delay in the in-service date of the Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line, the reconfiguration and delay in operation of the Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson transmission project and the reduction in distribution spending.
In fact, distribution spending is lower by about $425 million through 2012 versus the prior guidance we gave you earlier in the year. This should increase the proportion of our expenditures that earn a contemporaneous return. For example, transmission-related capital spending now represents $3.1 billion or about 50% of the capital budget for the 4-year period. Of course the number of these transmission projects depend upon our receipt of all the necessary approvals.
At the end of 2013, PSE&G's investment in transmission would represent about 31% of its consolidated rate base. Distribution-related capital spending is forecast at $2.2 billion for 2010 to 2013.
Future capital spending on distribution is aligned with the forecast levels of depreciation to support earning our authorized return.
PSE&G's investment program is expected to result in annual rate-based growth of about 9.5% per year over this period. Supportive regulatory recovery mechanisms and a constant focus on cost control should support PSE&G's earning its authorized return, with growth in capital providing for growth in PSE&G's earnings. For the past 12-month period, PSE&G's distribution ROE was 9.5%, reflecting only one quarter of results since the completion of the rate case.
Now I'll turn to PSEG Energy Holdings. Energy Holdings reported operating earnings of $24 million or $0.05 per share for the third quarter of 2010 versus an operating loss of $1 million during the third quarter of 2009. Operating earnings benefited from the successful termination of 2 cross-border leases during the quarter, which resulted in a gain of $0.03 per share, which matched the similar level of termination-related gains recorded in the year-ago quarter. And results also benefited from the absence of a premium paid on the debt exchange with Power of $0.04 per share as well as a decline in interest expense of $0.01 per share.
The successful termination of the 2 cross-border leases during the quarter reduced Holdings' potential net cash exposure to $330 million on this issue at the end of September. And recall that Holdings has $320 million on deposit with the IRS to defray potential interest costs associated with this issue.
Holdings' operating earnings for 2010 are forecast at $30 million to $40 million compared to 2009's operating earnings of $43 million. The loss of income on terminated leases and a reduction in gains from the termination of leases will be partially offset by lower financing costs and tax benefits from the startup of solar projects in Ohio and Florida.
Finally, a few other items. PSEG Power indicated during the quarter that it's exploring the potential sale of our two 1,000 megawatt each combined cycle generation facilities in Texas through an auction process. The sale is dependent upon the receipt of offers that we feel reflect the appropriate value for the assets. And should we decide to sell, the schedule would call for closing to occur during the first quarter of 2011.
Finally, just to note, we completed several transactions during the quarter at PSE&G to finance its capital program and refinance high-cost debt. We issued $250 million of tenure paper at 3.5% and refinanced $100 million of 6.4% tax-exempt bonds with the issuance of tax-exempt paper as multi-mode or annual put bonds with an initial term rate of 1.2%. Holdings recently announced its intention to call debt in December 2010 for the redemption of the remaining $127 million of outstanding principal balance of its 8.5% senior notes that are due in June 2011.
Those conclude my remarks and comments on some of our financings. I'd now like to turn the call back to Ralph for some final comments before, of course, we open the call up to your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Caroline. A few points to highlight. In conversations with many of you, we have heard concern expressed about transmission, and we've heard concern about migration and the impact on Power's margins. We hope that we've answered your questions surro
componenttext:
Thanks, Caroline. A few points to highlight. In conversations with many of you, we have heard concern expressed about transmission, and we've heard concern about migration and the impact on Power's margins. We hope that we've answered your questions surrounding transmission. Now while it isn't easy to build these lines, we're committed to investing in the projects that will improve the reliability of our system. And as you can see, it remains the single largest capital program for PSE&G.
We've also provided you with some guidance around the potential impact of migration on our results. While we're not pleased with the associated loss of margin, the more fundamental concern is the forward price of natural gas and its effect on electricity prices. And candidly, we're pleased to see some of you have addressed this issue in your forecast. Now while we aren't immune to declining prices, we are working to mitigate the impact through cost control where we can and through growth investments.
So now we'll open up the lines for your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Daniel Eggers of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the increase in transmission CapEx, could you guys talk a little more about how much of that spending has been, I guess, walked down through the approval process and what major projects we need to follow that to deliver or convert the planned CapE
componenttext: Yes, on the increase in transmission CapEx, could you guys talk a little more about how much of that spending has been, I guess, walked down through the approval process and what major projects we need to follow that to deliver or convert the planned CapEx into real spending?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, there's multiple approval processes. So it starts with a designation by PJM that it's in the RTEP, the Regional Transmission Expansion Plan, and it's safe to conclude that all of these projects are in the RTEP and all of the expenditure level. Then t
componenttext: Dan, there's multiple approval processes. So it starts with a designation by PJM that it's in the RTEP, the Regional Transmission Expansion Plan, and it's safe to conclude that all of these projects are in the RTEP and all of the expenditure level. Then there's the rate treatment at FERC, and as you know, we have a macro level formula rate treatment at FERC. Some of the projects received a different level of formula rate treatment, incentive adders, construction work in progress, and we have received that -- those 2 for Susquehanna-Roseland. We had received that for Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson when it was a 500-kilovolt project. Now that it's been redone, we're back with FERC to talk to them about the returns, if that will be granted. As you see, as they go down this path of what approvals you need, the path gets wider and wider with many more branches and tributaries off of it. The widest set of branches and tributaries are, of course, the environmental approvals and the siding approvals, which I just don't have information on my fingertips about what all -- what each of these projects are still lacking. Clearly, for Susquehanna-Roseland, as we've disclosed in the past, we're working with the National Park Service towards a 2012 approval date there.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, to put them in the capital budget, you guys to have a higher level of confidence on conversion as the portfolio is laid out today. Or how does that level of confidence [indiscernible] would have been a year ago?
componenttext: I guess, to put them in the capital budget, you guys to have a higher level of confidence on conversion as the portfolio is laid out today. Or how does that level of confidence [indiscernible] would have been a year ago?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, higher for a simple reason that, well, first of all, we made a lot of progress on S-R, and we now know what the obstacles are, and that's resulted in delay. But probably more importantly, all the other projects are 230kV and below, and many of them ar
componenttext: No, higher for a simple reason that, well, first of all, we made a lot of progress on S-R, and we now know what the obstacles are, and that's resulted in delay. But probably more importantly, all the other projects are 230kV and below, and many of them are underground. And they don't engender the kind of siding opposition that 500kV-aboveground projects engender.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so other -- how many of these are kind of big profile lines relative to your small $50 million, $100 million investment-type of projects?
componenttext: Okay. And so other -- how many of these are kind of big profile lines relative to your small $50 million, $100 million investment-type of projects?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends on how you define big in profile. I would say that 500kV is the one that attracts the greatest attention, and that would be Susquehanna-Roseland. Now the next step below that is 230kV for our system, that's Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson, but
componenttext: Well, it depends on how you define big in profile. I would say that 500kV is the one that attracts the greatest attention, and that would be Susquehanna-Roseland. Now the next step below that is 230kV for our system, that's Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson, but that's -- a large part of that is an underground construction. So an underground tends to not attract the same amount of concern because it's underground. I'm sorry, but I don't know how else to complete that sentence. So I'd say the one that's still is the primary focus of attention is Susquehanna-Roseland.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dan, this is Caroline, just one other thought. As you look at the numbers here and think about the modeling of our spend, one of the things to keep in mind, as you know, the in-service states for Susquehanna-Roseland and Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson wer
componenttext: And Dan, this is Caroline, just one other thought. As you look at the numbers here and think about the modeling of our spend, one of the things to keep in mind, as you know, the in-service states for Susquehanna-Roseland and Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson were delayed, as we said. So in these numbers that we included on Slide 25, just for your information, for Susquehanna-Roseland, we estimate that about $550 million of the total of up to $750 million is in the numbers through 2013, and for Branchburg-Roseland-Hudson, about $250 million to $275 million of the total of $700 million is in the numbers through 2013. So there is some spend, as you would expect, on these projects that's outside our forecast period through 2013, given their in-service states. So if you look at those 2 big amounts and you look at this CapEx for transmission just so you can keep the time here in proportionality, that might be helpful.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and not to upset Kathleen, but just to clarify, one last question. All of this transmission CapEx you assume is going get [indiscernible]. Is there going to be a subset that wouldn't because they're not discreet rate-making...
componenttext: Okay, and not to upset Kathleen, but just to clarify, one last question. All of this transmission CapEx you assume is going get [indiscernible]. Is there going to be a subset that wouldn't because they're not discreet rate-making...

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's right. All this transmission gets formula rate treatment, just the big projects gets sea whip [ph] . And right now, the only one that's approved for see whip is S-R. So it's that the logic being, of course, that the smaller projects go in-service m
componenttext: That's right. All this transmission gets formula rate treatment, just the big projects gets sea whip [ph] . And right now, the only one that's approved for see whip is S-R. So it's that the logic being, of course, that the smaller projects go in-service much more quickly, so the formula rate treatment gets you as close to the contemporary's returns for the fields they need to get you.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just have -- everything you've articulated is crystal-clear, but there was one thing I wanted a little more color on, if possible. You talked about in the first whole paragraph in the press release on PSE&G Power, a $0.02 decline in earnings associated
componenttext: I just have -- everything you've articulated is crystal-clear, but there was one thing I wanted a little more color on, if possible. You talked about in the first whole paragraph in the press release on PSE&G Power, a $0.02 decline in earnings associated with wholesale electricity energy supply contracts that you supplied from the market. Can you go into little more detail on what that activity is and what the sort of aggregate contribution is, if possible?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Greg, thanks for the question. Yes, so we've talked about some of these before, and these are low transactions that we bid on that -- in most part, low transactions that we bid on, whose power we supply through the market. And so because they're not
componenttext: Sure, Greg, thanks for the question. Yes, so we've talked about some of these before, and these are low transactions that we bid on that -- in most part, low transactions that we bid on, whose power we supply through the market. And so because they're not supplied from our assets, we treat these on a marked-to-market basis. And so every quarter, we are marking both sides of that transaction to market, and we're putting any changes in that through the P&L. So the primary driver of what you see here in the $0.02 is really a function of the same dynamics that are going on in the base business, and that is, in these low contracts, there is still opportunity for migration out of those types of account contracts by the provider. And so as migration is expected or experienced, and then we forecast it going forward to a large extent based on the experience that we have. We reduced the value of those contracts in terms of what they would return to the company, and therefore, we take that mark because they are marked to market directly in our earnings as we update those forecasts. So think of this as mark-to-market. It's not cash, but it's the representation, our best representation of the change in value of those contracts primarily driven by the same thing we talk about in the base business, which is the migration out of these full-requirement, polar-like contracts.

componenttext: Basically, I would just wanted to sort of touch base on the Texas sale. Sort of what should we think about being the potential size of these proceeds? And what's your expectation might be to deal with the proceeds, I mean, in terms of what you might -- what the use of proceeds might be?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, we're right, and you can respect that fact that we're right in the middle of the sales process now, so we couldn't even come close to remarking on that question, in terms of what we expect the size of proceeds. In terms of the use of the proceeds, i
componenttext: Paul, we're right, and you can respect that fact that we're right in the middle of the sales process now, so we couldn't even come close to remarking on that question, in terms of what we expect the size of proceeds. In terms of the use of the proceeds, if we sell, and we're exploring to sale, so we're not sure, we think we have some good opportunities to deploy capital. There's no surprises in there, it's what you've been hearing from us. We have a large capital program in utilities with a nearly 10% CAGR associated with it, and there's some opportunities perhaps to revisit some of those programs and expand them. Our infrastructure is not getting any younger, and we have found some opportunities in Holdings with some attractive terms and conditions with creditworthy counterparties and their PPAs on the renewable side. We have some peakers we're building in Power, some upgrades in our nuclear plants that we're looking at that are now within the planning horizon. So we think we have some good opportunities in our core business to deploy that capital, if we opt to sell.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. So we only have one lease remaining. In terms of to think about it, as you know, from what we've talking about over the past year, the team's been working hard to terminate these leases at appropriate terms. So as you think about all the lease
componenttext: Okay, sure. So we only have one lease remaining. In terms of to think about it, as you know, from what we've talking about over the past year, the team's been working hard to terminate these leases at appropriate terms. So as you think about all the leases that we've terminated, what's essentially happened is we reduced our tax liability essentially by the cash received from the counterparties coming in and going out. So if the terms are appropriate, we would look to terminate this last lease, but of course, we have to talk to the counterparties. If not, we keep the lease. One thing to keep in mind, though, that the termination of the lease and where we are with the IRS, those 2 things can continue to happen independent of each other to some extent. Now you still have to terminate all your leases to try to have the settlement with the IRS. Given what we have now, our exposure on a total basis is about $330 million, and we're continuing to have discussions with the IRS to see if we can come to terms. We'll try to do that. At the same time, we'll continue to try to terminate this lease. So you can really -- one is not dependent on the other, you can really pursue both paths, and that's exactly what we're doing. Given the size of the remaining lease, though, in terms of it impact to earnings, it will be marginal in terms of what might happen either from its earnings proceeds next year or termination. As you know, we have 2 leases this quarter, and it's just $0.03. So it's really a small number, and I think it's a credit to the team's work to really bring us down to only 1 lease left.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Paul, it's Ralph. Thank you, by the way, for recognizing the condition of the balance sheet. We are proud of that. We've worked hard for 4 years now, at least, to get it to where it is, and we are pleased with that condition. Most of our long investors
componenttext: So Paul, it's Ralph. Thank you, by the way, for recognizing the condition of the balance sheet. We are proud of that. We've worked hard for 4 years now, at least, to get it to where it is, and we are pleased with that condition. Most of our long investors tell us, "Look, we look to you to find good ways to deploy capital. And if you can get us risk -- attractive risk-adjusted returns, then we want you to use it in that way." So we are obviously disclosing to you the things that we have a high degree of confidence we can invest in. What I was trying to say earlier to Paul was that there are many things like that, that we consider all the time. Some of them we shred the paper and said, "That one didn't pan up that way we want." But there are others that are percolating and all organic in nature that we like, and we think we can put that money to good use. So I'd rather grow the business with attractive risk-adjusted returns and then create a positive MPV [ph] investment for our shareholders than something that just is a 0 MPV [ph].

componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, there were a number of unresolved issues in the rate cases that were supposed to be dealt with in separate proceedings. Have those proceedings started? And can you just give us an idea of where you are on those issues?
componenttext: As a follow-up, there were a number of unresolved issues in the rate cases that were supposed to be dealt with in separate proceedings. Have those proceedings started? And can you just give us an idea of where you are on those issues?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So there were 2 issues in particular, one related to a tariff rate that Power had pertaining to gas purchases. I guess we're about to disclose in the Q so I shouldn't front-run that, where that stands, But we have been in settlement discussions, and we'll
componenttext: So there were 2 issues in particular, one related to a tariff rate that Power had pertaining to gas purchases. I guess we're about to disclose in the Q so I shouldn't front-run that, where that stands, But we have been in settlement discussions, and we'll have a little bit more color in that in the Q. Suffice to say that there was a prior published date of October 25 when the hearings would take place, and you can go to the BP website to see if those hearings have not taken place and draw your own conclusions from that. The second issue is consolidated taxes, and there have been a series of extensions have been granted to us to file for a full-blown proceeding on consolidated taxes and how those are applied not just to us but to all utilities in New Jersey, inclusive of water utilities and gas utilities. So that's still in the regulatory calendar being pushed off a bit.

componenttext: Sure. So Paul, as I mentioned, we are burning more coal, right? So as we burn more coal, we bring the inventory down and some of the higher-priced inventory comes off, and we have lower-priced inventory that we're burning. Also keep in mind, we talked about earlier this year that the price of our Adaro coal relative to last year also came down. So that really moderated our coal costs overall as we burned more -- burnt down the inventories and has some lower-priced coal from Adaro.

componenttext: Jonathan, that one's tough to predict.
